title: Is it really necessary to use the Oxford comma? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don’t think it matters that much, except when it’s needed for clarity. The same question was asked on another forum. Here’s an example:“I love my parents, Lady Gaga and Humpty Dumpty.” With that one comma. the sentence says that my parents are Lady Gaga and Humpty Dumpty. The Oxford comma clears the mystery:“I love my parents, Lady Gaga, and Humpty Dumpty.” Another example:“Amanda found herself in the Winnebago with her ex-boyfriend, an herbalist and a pet detective.” Is her boyfriend an herbalist and pet detective? Or is it:“Amanda found herself in the Winnebago with her ex-boyfriend, an herbalist, and a pet detective.”

It is not optional if your publisher or employer requires it. And it is really necessary NOT to use it if your publisher prohibits it. I’ve written several books for commercial publishers. Their house style requires the Oxford comma. Why on earth would I not follow their policies? On the other hand, my husband writes a newspaper column every week. Journalists don’t use the Oxford comma. Why on earth would I insert it into his work? When you’re writing strictly for yourself, it’s your choice. I like the Oxford comma, and I use it in letters and emails. If you don’t like it, feel free not to use it — as long as you’re writing independently and not on behalf of a company or organization that requires it.
